unless otherwise noted, all figures in this emodule are from gray’s anatomy for students, 3e, by drake , vogl, & mitchell, © 2015 by elsevier. this is a recommended resource click to continue click to continue click to continue emodule tutorial emodule tutorial emodule tutorial

the brains with which you are supplied were fixed with formaldehyde, but they have been thoroughly rinsed with water to clear the formaldehyde, and are kept in water. brain tissue dries out very rapidly. keep the parts you are not using in the bucket, covered completely with a cloth, and with the lid on the bucket. moisten the parts you are using from time to time with water (not embalming fluid). a brown colouration on the edges of the brain tissue is a cry for moisture. look around yourself in the lab. you will see buckets labelled “human tissue only”. all waste tissue must be placed in the "human tissue only" buckets that are present in every laboratory. do not put waste tissue in the trolleys under the tables; these are dedicated containers for the remains of the cadaver(s) on that table. used paper towels and gloves go in the garbage, never in the “human tissue only” receptacles. trays, instruments and table tops are to be cleaned with cleaning fluid and paper towels. remember: the teaching labs are used by other student groups, and so must be left as you found them: clean and ready for student use. unit 6 care of human brain tissue previous next

we have been challenged with teaching / learning neuroanatomy over a short period of time. it’s critical that you learn what i teach, as i teach it. with neuroanatomy, more so than any other topic in anatomy, each lesson builds on the last. you will only frustrate yourself if you do delay learning. in unit 6, there is a lot more content that i’ll assign in the form of self-learning modules. i do, however, walk you through a fair bit of it using slide talks. clinical neuroanatomy is ultimately about two questions: 1) where is the lesion? and 2) what is the lesion? you first must learn some neuroanatomy before you can localize a lesion, so you’ll start with that. labs are run differently in unit 6. groups will be smaller (4-5 people) because the specimens you will study, brains and brainstems, are smaller. at stg, each lab room is equipped with 8 stations, each of which includes a whole brain and a half brain. stg students will be divided into 8 groups as follows: pairs 1 (a1 & b1) on the left side of the room go to one table, forming group ab1 pairs 2 (a2 & b2) on the left side of the room go to the next table, forming group ab2 pairs 3 (a3 & b3) on the left side of the room go to the third table, forming group ab3 pairs 4 (a4 & b4) on the left side of the room go to the fourth table, forming group ab4 similarly, on the right side of the room, four groups are formed designated cd1, cd2, cd3 and cd4. some resources are limited; you will rotate through the practical exercises in these groups so as to equitably share the specimens. at mam, students are divided into six groups of 4-5 students each. your ta will fill you in on the details. unit 6 overview previous next

prior to the lab period, you will complete prelab slms 19a through 19d. each ends with a quiz that will help you prepare for the lab rats that will be held at 9:00 am and 1:00 pm. you will find problems to solve in each of these modules. students are not expected to come having solved all of the problems in the modules, but are expected to come having prepared answers to the four or five problems that are assigned to them. below are the slide numbers on which there are problems to solve, and the pairs that must come having attempted to solve them. these pairs will arrive as the “experts” on these problems, and will teach the other students in their lettered groups. pairs 1: problems 19a.18, 19a.23 & 24, 19b.18, 19c.8, 19d.12 pairs 2: problems 19a.20, 19b.8, 19b.21, 19c.10, 19d.13 pairs 3: problems 19a.21, 19b.9, 19b.22, 19d.9 & 10 pairs 4: problems 19a.22, 19b.12, 19c.6, 19d.11 after the 9:00 am lab rat is over, experts will gather at a table and discuss their solutions to their assigned problems. tas will circulate to ensure that you’ve arrived reasonable solutions. this should take ~ 60 mins. after this initial period, experts will disband to their lettered groups, thus forming groups of 8-9 students that contain 2-3 experts on each question. during the next 2 hours or more, lettered groups will go through the questions in order, starting with those from prelab slm 19a. in the afternoon, students will complete exercises 19.1 and 19.2, each of which should take 90 minutes. review these exercises before the lab so that your time in lab is used efficiently. in particular, review the brief videos in these exercises prior to lab. you mustn’t look at them for the first time during the lab! lab 19 instructions previous take me to exercise selection

previous next using the emodule use this emodule before labs to prepare for them, during labs to guide your studies, and after labs as a review tool. to complete each section, use the next button at the bottom of the pages, swipe right or press the right arrow key to move forward one page at a time. use the menu, available by clicking “menu” at the top, to navigate to specific slides. use search to quickly find instances of relevant terms. use the previous button at the bottom of the pages, swipe left or press the left arrow key to move back one page at a time. lab 19 19a prelab 19b prelab 19c prelab

previous got it, let’s move on conventions used in the emodule with age, wear and tear, info information that has implications for health and disease is introduced on a blue bar and continued below the bar: and how the superior and inferior articular facets of adjacent vertebrae articulate with one another. note how they fit together, tas k tasks, introduced on a pink bar and continued below the bar in bold, are actions that you should take to help you understand the content: an intervertebral disc can herniate, such that the nucleus pulposus…. the film button appears on the bottom bar of slides where a video accompanies tasks or explanations. the photo button appears at the bottom of slides where a photo accompanies tasks. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to open related content. click the icon to close it. some words are followed by an icon ; click the icon to see a definition. words / phrases in purple denote concepts with which you should become familiar. the slide talk icon appears on the top bar of slides containing a recording of me explaining concepts

lab 19 exercise selection lab 19 exercises 19.1 blood supply of the cns 19.1 blood supply of the cns 19.1 blood supply of the cns 19.3 field trip 19.3 field trip 19.3 field trip pre-lab slms if you finish any exercise early… 19a prelab slm: motor pathways 19a prelab slm: motor pathways 19a prelab slm: motor pathways review lab 19 19d prelab slm: lesion localization 19d prelab slm: lesion localization 19d prelab slm: lesion localization 19b prelab slm: sensory pathways 19b prelab slm: sensory pathways 19b prelab slm: sensory pathways 19c prelab slm: the brainstem internal 19c prelab slm: the brainstem internal 19c prelab slm: the brainstem internal quizlandia 19 quizlandia 19 quizlandia 19 19.2 the medullary centre 19.2 the medullary centre 19.2 the medullary centre

19a motor pathways back to exercise selection next objectives when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the motor pathway from the cerebral cortex to muscle, and how movements are generated. describe and distinguish the clinical features of upper motor neuron and lower motor neuron syndromes, and demonstrate how these features can be used to localize the lesion.

19a motor pathways consist of a two-neuron chain the upper motor neuron (umn) a. its cell body is located in “higher” centers of the cns (cerebral ctx, brainstem) b. its axon projects through the nervous system to synapse onto: the lower motor neuron (lmn) c. its cell body is located in a lower center of the cns (the brainstem or spinal cord) d. its axon travels via a peripheral nerve to synapse onto: e. striated muscle at the neuromuscular junction (nmj) 2 previous next
19a part 1: the lower motor neuron 3 previous next motor pathways part 1: the lower motor neuron (lmn)

19a lmns are in the brainstem and spinal cord 4 previous next in the brainstem: cell bodies of lmns are located in certain cranial nerve nuclei axons of lmns reach their target muscle by traveling in a cranial nerve to the nmj at their target muscle in the spinal cord: cell bodies of lmns are located in the ventral horn axons of lmns travel in the ventral root, spinal nerve, dorsal / ventral ramus, peripheral nerve to the nmj at their target muscle

19a lmns are “the final common pathway” 5 previous next umns in several locations send signals to the lmn, however: the lmn is the only neuron that contacts the muscle therefore the lmn is the “final common pathway” (sherrington) lmns are large multipolar neurons with extensive dendritic trees that receive and integrate all the incoming signals

19a lmns form motor columns 6 previous next in the brainstem, lmns form a discontinuous series of motor nuclei associated with some cranial nerves in the spinal cord, lmns form the ventral horns. remember: the ventral horns are enlarged at cervical and lumbosacral levels to accommodate the lmns that innervate limbs lmns of the ventral horns innervate ipsilateral muscles.  lesions of spinal lmns or their axons have ipsilateral effects

19a the stretch reflex 7 previous next the stretch reflex maintains muscle length. passive muscle stretch triggers active muscle contraction. certain spinal levels tested with a reflex hammer, e.g. c6 = biceps c7 = triceps l4 = patellar s1 = achilles basic clinical neuroscience, 2e, by young et al., © 2008. the stretch reflex requires an intact reflex arc.  a lmn lesion abolishes the stretch reflex. normally, the stretch reflex is suppressed by input from umns.  an umn lesion enhances the stretch reflex.

19a lower motor neuron lesions 8 previous next ipsilateral weakness: the target muscle becomes weak or, if all of its motor neurons are damaged, paralysed. usually individual muscles are affected rather than groups of muscles. hyporeflexia: reflex activity is diminished or abolished because the lmn forms the efferent part of the reflex arc. flaccid paralysis: normal (not ↓) muscle tone in the target muscles. atrophy: loss of trophic substances from the nerve results in death of muscle fibres and a marked ↓ muscle mass over time. fasciculations: visible twitching of muscle fibers occurs in the early stage of wasting.

19a lmns in cranial nerve nuclei 9 previous next in the spinal cord: remember: lmns of the ventral horn innervate ipsilateral targets  lmn lesions in the spinal cord, of a spinal nerve, or of a peripheral nerve always have ipsilateral effects in the brainstem: lmns in cranial nerve nuclei also innervate ipsilateral targets  lesions of a cn nucleus containing lmns or of a cranial nerve containing motor axons always have ipsilateral effects with one (unimportant) exception…….

19a the exception 10 previous next lmns in the trochlear nucleus decussate, therefore: contralateral deficits with lesion of the trochlear nucleus but: ipsilateral deficits with lesion of the trochlear nerve
19a part 2: the upper motor neuron 11 previous next motor pathways part 2: the upper motor neuron (umn)

19a upper motor neurons 12 previous next lmns are influenced by umns originating in several locations, usually through interneurons. the vestibulospinal tract is involved in balance / equilibrium. the reticulospinal tract is involved in posture and gait. the rubrospinal tract influences upper limb flexors. the corticospinal tract is involved in skilled voluntary control of skeletal muscle

19a the lateral corticospinal tract (lcst) 13 previous next the lcst allows for skilled asymmetric limb mvt . cell bodies of umns are located in 1° motor cortex, i.e. the precentral gyrus . axons traverse the subcortical white matter of the cerebral hemisphere and the brainstem, until, at the junction of the brainstem and spinal cord, most fibres decussate and descend contralaterally in the lateral column of the spinal cord as the lcst. axons of the lcst synapse on lmns in the cervical & lumbosacral enlargements, which innervate distal limb musculature for discrete, skilled movement.

19a axons of the cst form many anatomical structures 14 previous next corona radiatasubcortical white matter internal capsulebetween diencephalon & basal nuclei cerebral pedunclesin midbrain pyramidsin medulla decussation of the pyramidsat spinomedullary junction lateral corticospinal tractin lateral funiculus

19a umn lesions: lcst 15 previous next lmn lesions umn lesions ipsilateral weakness hemiplegiacontralateral (a) or ipsilateral (b) hyporeflexia hyperreflexia flaccid paralysis - normal muscle tone spastic paralysis – increased muscle tone atrophy - marked disuse atrophy only, with time fasciculations initially no fasciculations babinski sign

19a the babinski sign 16 previous next basic clinical neuroscience, 2e, by young et al., © 2008. in an umn lesion, firm stroking of the sole of the foot causes dorsiflexion of the ankle, extension and spreading of the toes. this is the babinski sign. normally, this stimulus results in plantarflexion of ankle and flexion of toes, as if resisting the pressure of the ground against the sole of the foot. not surprisingly, the babinski sign is normally present in babies, and disappears as they learn to walk.

19a modulation of upper motor neurons 17 previous next umns of the cerebral ctx are modulated by the basal nuclei & cerebellum via the thalamus. damage to these structures does not manifest with the signs of an umn lesion. lesions here affect the quality of mvt, e.g. can cause decreased accuracy of movements or unwanted movements, such as tremors.

19a a summary of lmn & umn lesions 18 previous next remember: lmn lesions always have ipsilateral effects. this applies to lesions of axons of lmns within all spinal nerves and all cranial nerves (and their peripheral branches) this applies to lesions of cell bodies of lmns within the spinal cord and within cranial nerve nuclei . with the lcst, umn lesions might have ipsilateral or contralateral effects on the body, depending on the location of the lesion relative to the point of decussation of the umn. will lesion a cause an ipsilateral spastic paralysis or a contralateral spastic paralysis? will lesion b cause an ipsilateral spastic paralysis or a contralateral spastic paralysis? that’s why it’s important to know at what level a pathway decussates! what about umns that control lmns in cranial nerve nuclei? this projection is called the corticobulbar tract…

19a the corticobulbar tract (cbt) 19 previous next the cbt extends from the cortex to the “bulb” or brainstem. the cbt innervates lmns in the motor nuclei of cn v, vii, ix, x, xi and xii . summary: the motor nucleus of cn xii is controlled contralaterally, like the lcst. the motor nuclei of cns v, ix & x are controlled bilaterally. the control of the motor nucleus of cn vii is a little more complicated… we know that lesions of these cn nuclei and nerves have ipsilateral effects. let’s work out the effect of lesions of the umns in the cbt on each of these nerves / nuclei. in doing so, keep in mind that the point of decussation of the cbt is taken to be at the level of the target nucleus.

lmns in the hypoglossal nuclei control the ipsilateral muscles of the tongue via cn xii, the hypoglossal nerve. the function of cn xii is tested by asking the patient to stick out their tongue. if one side of the tongue is paralyzed, the tongue, on protrusion, will point toward the weakened side; i.e. the strong side dominates! in lesion a, the left hypoglossal nerve is affected . you ask the patient to stick out their tongue. what will happen? fill in the blank: “the tongue will point to the ______________ side, relative to the lesion.” like the cst, umns in the cbt largely innervate the lmns in the hypoglossal nucleus contralaterally, as illustrated in the graphic. in lesion b, the right cbt is affected. you ask the patient to stick out their tongue. what will happen? fill in the blank: “the tongue will point to the ______________ side, relative to the lesion.” 19a umn lesions affecting the hypoglossal nucleus 20 previous next

19a umn lesions affecting the masticator nucleus the masticator nucleus contains the cell bodies of lmns that control the ipsilateral muscles of mastication via v3, the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve. the function of the masticator nucleus / mandibular nerve is tested by asking the patient to protrude their jaw. again, the strong side dominates and pushes the jaw toward the weakened side. in lesion a, the left v3 nerve is affected. you ask the patient to stick out their tongue. what will happen? fill in the blank: “the jaw will point to the ______________ side, relative to the lesion.” umns in the cbt innervate these lmns bilaterally, as illustrated in the graphic. in lesion b, the right cbt is affected. you ask the patient to protrude their jaw. what will happen? notice that even with the cbt lesioned on one side, both masticator nuclei are receiving input from the unlesioned side. will the jaw protrude in the midline? or off to one side or the other? 21 previous next

19a umn lesions affecting the nucleus ambiguus 22 previous next the nucleus ambiguus contains the cell bodies of lmns that control the ipsilateral muscles of the larynx (speech) and pharynx (swallowing), largely via cn x, the vagus nerves . the function of the nucleus ambiguus / vagus nerve is assessed by listening to the patients voice, by testing the gag reflex and / or by having them open their mouth and say “ahhh”. if lesioned, you may observe a hoarse voice, and an absent gag reflex / sagging palate. in lesion a, the left vagus nerve is affected. you ask the patient to open their mouth and say, “ahhh”. then you test their gag reflex. fill in the blank: “the gag reflex will be absent and the palate will sag on the ______________ side, relative to the lesion.” umns in the cbt innervate these lmns bilaterally, as illustrated in the graphic. in lesion b, the right cbt is affected. you listen to the patient speak, ask them to open their mouth to say, “ahhh”, and test their gag reflex. what will you observe?

19a lmn lesions affecting the facial nucleus 23 previous next the facial nucleus is divided into two subnuclei: the rostral subnucleus innervates the frontalis (pink). the caudal subnucleus innervates the muscles of the lower face (red). the facial nucleus contains the cell bodies of lmns that control the ipsilateral muscles of facial expression via cn vii, the facial nerve. the function of the facial nucleus / nerve is tested by asking the patient to i) show their teeth, and ii) raise their eyebrows. in lesion a, the left facial nerve is affected. you ask the patient to show their teeth and raise their eyebrows. what will happen? fill in the blank: “the patient will be unable to raise their ______________ eye brow. in trying to show their teeth, the ___________ side of their face won’t move.”

19a umn lesions affecting the facial nucleus 24 previous next the two subnuclei are innervated differently by the cbt. the rostral subnucleus is innervated bilaterally (pale blue). the caudal subnucleus is innervated contralaterally (dark blue). in lesion b, the right cbt is affected. you ask the patient to show their teeth and raise their eyebrows. what will happen? will the patient be able to show their teeth on both sides? will the patient be able to raise their eyebrow on both sides?

19a quiz previous next 25 hmmm, why not? go to the quiz sorry, busy now. i’m setting up a date for tonight. skip the quiz you’ve reached the end of this exercise. do you want to take the end-of-exercise quiz?
previous congratulations on finishing prelab slm 19a! back to exercise selection back to exercise selection back to exercise selection review 19a review 19a review 19a

19b sensory pathways back to exercise selection next objectives when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the anatomical pathway for crude touch, nociception and temperature sensation from the body and face, and the clinical effects of lesions of this pathway. describe the anatomical pathway for discriminative touch, vibration and proprioception sensation from the body and face, and the clinical effects of lesions of this pathway. predict the deficit that would result from damage to the nervous system in different sites in terms of (i) the sensory modalities lost, (ii) the area of the body in which the deficit is perceived, and (iii) the side of the body affected, relative to the lesion. explain and distinguish between a dissociated sensory loss and a suspended sensory loss, and recognize their significance in lesion localization. integrate the effect of a lesion on motor function with the effect on sensory function.

19b sensory modalities there are five basic sensory modalities, each with submodalities. all of these modalities (except olfaction) relay through the thalamus on their way to perception in their 1° sensory cortex. smell vision taste hearing touch / general sensation touch has six submodalities, which can be assessed on the neurological exam: nociception (tissue damage) temperature (crude touch) light touch vibration sense proprioception 2 previous next these submodalities are carried in the spinothalamic tract. these submodalities are carried in the dorsal columns / medial lemniscus pathway.

19b perception occurs in modality-specific 1° sensory cortex 3 previous next superolateral surface of cerebral hemisphere. from serial dissection of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d. medial surface of cerebral hemisphere. in lab 18, you identified the following modality-specific 1° sensory cortices: 1° somatosensory ctx, located in the postcentral gyrus. here, general sensation, or touch to the surface of the body, is perceived. 1° auditory ctx is located in the transverse temporal gyri, on the superior surface of superior temporal gyrus. here, sound is perceived. 1° visual ctx is located in the gyri superior & inferior to the calcarine fissure. here, visual input from the retina is perceived. 1° olfactory ctx is located deep to the uncus, in the amygdala here, smell is perceived.

4 previous next 19b somatotopy in 1° somatosensory cortex many cns regions are arranged somatotopically. 1° somatosensory cortex is located in the postcentral gyrus. here, adjacent cortical regions receive information from adjacent body parts on the contralateral side. the size of the dedicated cortical region proportional to the density of innervation of the body part, not its physical size.

5 previous next 19b basic rules of somatosensory pathways while there are two, distinct somatosensory pathways to learn, the spinothalamic tract (stt) and the dorsal columns / medial lemniscus system (dc/ml), they share certain similarities. both pathways consist of a three neuron chain, these being the first order (1°), second order (2°), and third order (3°) neuron. we’ll colour code them here: the 1° neuron is pseudounipolar; its cell body is in a ganglion in the pns. for the body, its cell body is located in a dorsal root ganglion for the face, its cell body is (usually) in the trigeminal ganglion the 2° neuron is the one that varies between the two pathways, the stt and dc/ml. the cell body of the 2° neuron is in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord or a brainstem nucleus, and its axon projects to the contralateral thalamus. therefore it’s the axon of the 2° neuron that decussates. the cell body of the 3° neuron is located in the ventral posterior (vp) nucleus of the thalamus. its axon projects to 1° somatosensory (ss) cortex, where the sensation is perceived.

6 previous next 19b functional localization in spinal white matter stt: nociception & temperature ventral dorsal fasciculus cuneatus fasciculus gracilis dc/ml: light touch, vibration & conscious proprioception recall that the spinal white matter is divided, anatomically, into ventral, lateral and dorsal columns. in the spinal cord, the axons comprising the stt are located in a ventrolateral position. in the spinal cord, the axons comprising the dc/ml comprise the dorsal columns.

7 previous next 19b sensory pathways pt 1: the stt 1° neurons: cell bodies in drg in the pns axons project to cns via dorsal roots, synapse onto: 2° neurons: cell bodies in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord; axons decussate ascend in the spinothalamic tract (stt) of the ventrolateral column becomes the spinal lemniscus (sl) in brainstem, synapse onto: 3°neurons: cell bodies in the vp thalamus & project to: 1° somatosensory cortex in the postcentral gyrus nociception & temperature sense from the body

8 previous next 19b central cord lesion the figure on the left shows the stt forming throughout the length of the neuraxis, collecting information from lumbar, thoracic and cervical levels in syringomyelia, the central canal expands, and initially, it selectively destroys the decussating 2° sensory fibres of the stt. click here: to place this lesion at thoracic levels. which sensory modalities would be lost, and which would be retained? would motor function be affected by the lesion at this early stage, as depicted by the blue circle? with reference to the figure on the right, describe the distribution of the sensory loss . click here: to move the lesion to the cervical cord, where syringomyelia most commonly develops. now describe the distribution of the sensory loss, again with reference to the figure on the right.

9 previous next 19b extramedullary and intramedullary lesions illustrated in the previous slide and on the right is the somatotopy within the stt. more and more axons are added to the stt as it ascends the spinal cord. lesions can impinge on and damage the cns from the outside (e.g. meningioma) or from within (e.g. tumor). these are described as extramedullary and intramedullary lesions, respectively. click here to add a slow-growing extramedullary lesion that would compress the stt from superficial to deep. describe how the patient’s symptoms would develop over time. what modalities would be affected? what side? distribution (i.e. body part affected first, and later, as the tumor grows) click here to add a slow-growing extramedullary lesion that would compress the stt from deep to superficial. describe how the patient’s symptoms would develop over time. what modalities would be affected? what side? distribution (i.e. body part affected first, and later, as the tumor grows)

10 previous next 19b what about the face? nociception and temperature sensation from the face is a variation on the stt. remember the rules? the 1° neuron is pseudounipolar; its cell body is in a ganglion in the pns. for the body, its cell body is located in a dorsal root ganglion for the face, its cell body is (usually) in the trigeminal ganglion the 2° neuron is the one that varies between the two pathways, the stt and dc/ml. the cell body of the 2° neuron is in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord or a brainstem nucleus, and its axon projects to the contralateral thalamus. therefore it’s the axon of the 2° neuron that decussates. the cell body of the 3° neuron is located in the ventral posterior (vp) nucleus of the thalamus. its axon projects to 1° somatosensory (ss) cortex, where the sensation is perceived.

19b nociception & temp sensation from the face 11 previous next the trigeminal nerve carries all somatosensory information from the face. the cell bodies of these 1° sensory neurons are in the trigeminal ganglion. the trigeminal nerve enters the brainstem, and those axons carrying nociception and temperature sensation form the spinal trigeminal tract. these axons synapse onto the cell bodies of 2° sensory neurons in the spinal trigeminal nucleus. the spinal trigeminal nucleus is an extension of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord in the brainstem. the axons of these 2° sensory neurons decussate and join the spinal lemniscus. remember, the spinal lemniscus is carrying nociception and temperature sensation from the contralateral body, and now this information from the face joins it. the axons of the spinal lemniscus synapse onto the cell bodies of the 3° neurons in the vp nucleus of the thalamus. the axons of the 3° neurons project to 1° somatosensory cortex.

12 previous next 19b summary: nociception & temp sensation in this summary, the pathways for pain and temperature from the right side of the body (represented by the leg) and face are both shown. two lesions are added, one in the spinal cord, and one in the brainstem. for each lesion, answer these three questions: 1. which sensory modalities will be lost? 2. what region of the body will lose these modalities of sensation? 3. will the loss of sensation be bilateral, or will it be ipsilateral or contralateral to the lesion? a b

13 previous next 19b sensory pathways pt 2: the dc/ml the general sensory modalities of fine touch, vibration sense and conscious proprioception travel in the dorsal columns / medial lemniscus system. this pathway follows the rules. remember the rules? we’ll first look at this system, as applied to the body. the 1° neuron is pseudounipolar; its cell body is in a ganglion in the pns. for the body, its cell body is located in a dorsal root ganglion for the face, its cell body is (usually) in the trigeminal ganglion the 2° neuron is the one that varies between the two pathways, the stt and dc/ml. the cell body of the 2° neuron is in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord or a brainstem nucleus, and its axon projects to the contralateral thalamus. therefore it’s the axon of the 2° neuron that decussates. the cell body of the 3° neuron is located in the ventral posterior (vp) nucleus of the thalamus. its axon projects to 1° somatosensory (ss) cortex, where the sensation is perceived.

14 previous next 19b functional localization in spinal white matter stt: nociception & temperature ventral dorsal fasciculus cuneatus fasciculus gracilis dc/ml: light touch, vibration & conscious proprioception remember this? in the spinal cord, the axons comprising the stt are located in a ventrolateral position. in the spinal cord, the axons comprising the dc/ml comprise the dorsal columns.

15 previous next 19b fasciculus gracilis and cuneatus dorsal view of the cervical spinal cord. from neuroanatomy: an atlas of structures, sections, and systems, 7th ed., by duane e. haines, © 2007 identify the dorsal columns of white matter in this image. as you know, they lie between the dorsal median sulcus and the dorsal lateral sulcus. note, however, that at this level, a third sulcus subdivides the dorsal column into the fasciculus gracilis (more medial) and the fasciculus cuneatus (more lateral). both of these tracts carry fine touch, vibration sense and conscious proprioception from the ipsilateral body. the difference is in the body region. the fasciculus gracilis carries these sensations from the lower body, inc. the leg. it is therefore present in the dorsal column throughout the length of the spinal cord. the fasciculus cuneatus carries these sensations from the upper body, inc. the arm. it is therefore present in the dorsal column only at upper thoracic and cervical levels. we’ll start with the lower body.

16 previous next 19b dc/ml: leg 1° neurons: cell bodies in drg in the pns axons project to cns via dorsal roots, and ascend in the ipsilateral fasciculus gracilis (fg) synapse onto: 3°neurons: cell bodies in the vp thalamus, axons project to: 1° somatosensory cortex in the postcentral gyrus fine touch, vibration sense & conscious from the leg. 2° neurons: cell bodies in the nucleus gracilis (ng) of the medulla axons decussate, ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus (ml) synapse onto:

17 previous next 19b dc/ml: arm 1° neurons: cell bodies in drg in the pns axons project to cns via dorsal roots, and ascend in the ipsilateral fasciculus cuneatus (fc) synapse onto: 3°neurons: cell bodies in the vp thalamus, axons project to: 1° somatosensory cortex in the postcentral gyrus fine touch, vibration sense & conscious from the arm. 2° neurons: cell bodies in the nucleus cuneatus (nc) of the medulla axons decussate, ascend contralaterally in the medial lemniscus (ml) synapse onto:

18 previous next 19b somatotopy in the dorsal columns as you ascend the spinal cord, more and more axons, from each successive dermatome, are added to the dc from its lateral aspect. therefore a somatotopy develops in which axons carrying fine touch, vibration sense and conscious proprioception are organized such that those from sacral / coccygeal (s/co) dermatomes are most medial, followed by those from lumbar (l), thoracic (t), and finally, those from cervical (c) dermatomes are most lateral. this is a cross-section of the spinal cord at the level of the cervical enlargement. i’ve placed a hypothetical lesion in the dorsal median fissure. this is a slow-growing lesion that, over time, expands laterally, both right and left. from the human brain in photographs and diagrams, 4e, by j. nolte and j. b. angevine, jr., © 2013. answer three questions: 1. what somatosensory modalities will be lost? 2. what body region will lose these sensations first? what body region will lose these sensations last? 3. which word describes the distribution of the deficit? bilateral, ipsilateral or contralateral?

19 previous next 19b what about the face? fine touch from the face is a variation on the dc/ml . remember the rules? the 1° neuron is pseudounipolar; its cell body is in a ganglion in the pns. for the body, its cell body is located in a dorsal root ganglion for the face, its cell body is (usually) in the trigeminal ganglion the 2° neuron is the one that varies between the two pathways, the stt and dc/ml. the cell body of the 2° neuron is in the dorsal horn of the spinal cord or a brainstem nucleus, and its axon projects to the contralateral thalamus. therefore it’s the axon of the 2° neuron that decussates. the cell body of the 3° neuron is located in the ventral posterior (vp) nucleus of the thalamus. its axon projects to 1° somatosensory (ss) cortex, where the sensation is perceived.

20 previous next 19b light touch from the face the trigeminal nerve carries all somatosensory information from the face. the cell bodies of these 1° sensory neurons are in the trigeminal ganglion. the trigeminal nerve enters the brainstem, and those axons carrying light touch sensation synapse onto the cell bodies of 2° sensory neurons in the chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve. the chief sensory nucleus is, for the ipsilateral face, what the nucleus gracilis is for the ipsilateral leg . the axons of these 2° sensory neurons decussate and join the medial lemniscus. remember, the medial lemniscus is carrying fine touch, vibration and conscious proprioception from the contralateral body, and now the same information from the face joins it. the axons of the medial lemniscus synapse onto the cell bodies of the 3° neurons in the vp nucleus of the thalamus. the axons of the 3° neurons project to 1° somatosensory cortex.

(above? below?) what side of the body relative to the lesion? 19c the brainstem internal back to exercise selection next objectives when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the major functional groups of sensory and motor nuclei in the brainstem with respect to their locations, associated cranial nerves, and target structures and functions. identify / describe brainstem cross sections including the nuclei and tracts seen at each of six levels. predict the deficit that would result from a lesion of the brainstem at these 6 different levels.

19c the brainstem and long tract signs white matter tracts pass into and through the brainstem. damage to tracts passing through the brainstem affects information flow up or down the cns. this causes long-tract signs, in which the signs of the lesion are located in a body part far from the lesion . as a reminder of the three tracts you’ve learned: some tracts carry motor information downward. the corticobulbar tract brings motor commands from primary motor cortex to the brainstem nuclei associated with certain cranial nerves. the corticospinal tract carries motor commands from primary motor cortex through the brainstem to its point of decussation at the spinomedullary junction, and from there into the lateral column of spinal white matter . some tracts carry sensory information upward. the spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature information from the contralateral body into the brainstem, where it is joined by the same sensory modalities from the contralateral face, before ascending to primary somatosensory cortex via the thalamus . the dorsal columns carry fine touch, conscious proprioception and vibration sense from the ipsilateral body to the spinomedullary junction, where this information decussates to form the medial lemniscus. the medial lemniscus, now carrying information from the contralateral body, receives the same modalities from the contralateral face, and brings it to primary somatosensory cortex via the thalamus . lesions of the brainstem can affect one or more of these tracts resulting in contralateral long-tract signs , such as contralateral paralysis of the body and / or face, or contralateral loss of sensory modalities in the body and / or face. how does the clinician localize a lesion, using the neurological exam, to the brainstem? read on… 2 previous next

19c lesions of cranial nerve nuclei have ipsilateral effects 3 previous next cranial nerves iii and v - xii are associated with ipsilateral nuclei within the brainstem. lesions of most cranial nerve nuclei, therefore, have ipsilateral effects. it’s the combination of a cranial nerve deficit on one side of the face and long tract signs on the other side of the body that localizes a lesion to the brainstem level. these are called alternating signs. presented with a patient showing alternating signs, such as a left-sided paralysis of the tongue and right sided paralysis of the arm and leg, you can confidently suspect a brainstem lesion! however, with a little knowledge of the anatomy of the brainstem, you can localize the lesion to a very specific level of the brainstem. that is the purpose of learning the anatomy of the brainstem; to be able to localize a lesion to a specific brainstem level using your clinical skills. if that’s not a super power, i don’t know what is! the value in learning the external features of the brainstem is that it leads to an understanding of what lies beneath the surface at different levels, which is the key to localizing lesions. for instance, cranial nerve nuclei are usually at the same brainstem level as the point of origin of the associated nerve. therefore, now that you know the point of origin of the cranial nerves from the brainstem, you can infer the presence of the associated nuclei at that level.

19d lesion localization: an anatomist’s approach back to station selection next when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: name the four clinical levels of the nervous system. describe in general terms the neurological functions that are mediated by all four levels of the nervous system. describe the pattern of functional loss that would occur following injury to one of the four levels. localize a lesion to one of the four levels, given a case history.

19d the nervous system has four clinically recognized levels 2 previous next so far, you have been told where the lesion is, and asked to predict the resulting signs and symptoms. however, as a clinician, the order is reversed: the patient will present with a constellation of signs and symptoms, and your job will be to use your knowledge of neuroanatomy to deduce the location of the lesion. there are four clinically recognized levels to the nervous system, and lesions at each of these levels have distinct patterns. i’ll start by defining the levels: the supratentorial level (intracranial, superior to the tentorium cerebelli) includes the cerebral hemispheres & the intracranial portions of cranial ns i & ii. the infratentorial level (from the tentorial notch to the foramen magnum) includes the brainstem, cerebellum & the intracranial portions of cranial ns iii – xii. the spinal level includes the spinal cord. the peripheral level includes all of the cranial and spinal nerves, inc. the dorsal and ventral roots. lesions located in each of these four levels have common characteristics. knowing these common characteristics helps you to quickly narrow down the location of a nervous system lesion. this is what i want to teach you here.

19d longitudinal and segmental effects of lesions 3 previous next you have learned about long tracts (lcst, stt, dc/ml), that carry information up and down the neuraxis. the lesion of a tract is said to have longitudinal effects, because it interrupts information flow from one region of the nervous system to another. the effects of the lesion can be quite far from the anatomical location of the lesion (e.g. a lesion in your brain can paralyze your leg). you have learned about nerves and nuclei, that deliver sensory information into and / or motor information out of the nervous system. the lesion of a nerve or nucleus is said to have segmental effects, because the lesion is affecting information flow into the nervous system from some sense organ, or out of the nervous system, to some peripheral effector. also, there are functions that are restricted to a given region (e.g. language to the dominant hemisphere or respiration to the brainstem). these are considered segmental functions, too, so their loss is a segmental effect. the key to lesion localization is figuring out where the longitudinal effects intersect, anatomically, with the segmental effects, such that all signs and symptoms can be explained with a single lesion. luckily, there is a pattern to the presentation of lesions at each level of the nervous system. i’ll explain the four patterns and then we’ll work through some examples.

19d characteristics of supratentorial lesions 4 previous next segmental effects a loss of olfaction (cn i) a visual field deficit (cn ii) loss of higher cortical functions (language comprehension, language production, memory, cognition) endocrine disorders due to pituitary gland involvement symptoms of increased intracranial pressure (headache, nausea and vomiting, altered mental status, such as depressed level of alertness or attention) longitudinal effects loss of sensory & motor functions in the face, trunk and limbs on the side contralateral to the lesion(see fig.) altered autonomic functions due to effects on neural pathways descending from hypothalamus to the brainstem or spinal cord

19d characteristics of infratentorial lesions 5 previous next segmental effects re. cn iii – xii: destruction of cn nuclei or nerves leads to ipsilateral signs in the face altered respiration, cardiac functions incoordination of motor activities (cerebellum) depressed consciousness longitudinal effects destruction of descending or ascending pathways causes contralateral signs in the body autonomic control throughout the body \ lesions at the infratentorial level are characterized by signs on the ipsilateral side of the face and on the contralateral side of the body. (see figure) these are called “alternating signs”.

19d characteristics of spinal lesions 6 previous next segmental effects destruction of spinal grey matter can cause signs at the level of the lesion e.g. a loss of sensory input in a dermatomal distribution e.g. a loss of motor output in a myotomal distribution, i.e. involving specific muscles longitudinal effects destruction of ascending / descending pathways leads to sensory / motor signs below the level of the lesion deficits are frequently bilateral; i.e. there is a “level” below which signs are seen bilaterally (as compared to a supratentorial or infratentorial lesion which causes a loss on one side of the body – i.e. a hemiplegia)

19d characteristics of peripheral lesions 7 previous next segmental effects ipsilateral sensory and / or motor deficits in either a dermatomal / myotomal pattern or in a peripheral nerve distribution longitudinal effects none upshot: deficits are usually unilateral and regionally confined note: diseases of ventral horn cells show a peripheral pattern of effects, because there are no long track signs

19d some simple examples 8 previous next where’s the lesion, if the patient shows: a loss of sensory / motor function, on the same side of the face and body, and a loss of vision, disordered speech or higher function? “alternating signs”: sensory / motor signs on one side of the body and cranial nerve signs on the opposite side of the face? a loss of coordination, suggestive of cerebellar involvement? no cranial nerve signs, a loss of function at a certain dermatomal / myotomal level of the body and below? a loss of sensory and / or motor function in a dermatomal / myotomal distribution or in a peripheral nerve distribution, but no long-track signs (i.e. no “level”)? you get the idea: stand back, breathe, and look at the larger clinical picture, then make sense of the details. practice problems follow on the remaining slides….

19d question 1 9 previous next where’s the lesion? you are training in the stroke clinic, and, with your preceptor, you see a patient who was, a month earlier, brought to the emergency department by his wife because he suddenly developed right-sided weakness. you take his history, examine him and note the following: on protrusion, his tongue deviates to the left weakness of the right arm and leg, and a positive babinski sign a lack of fine touch, vibration sense and conscious proprioception throughout the right side of the body all other cranial nerve functions are normal pain and temperature sensation is intact throughout wow! sounds complicated! let’s break it down…..

19d question 1, cont. 10 previous next first thought: there are cranial nerve signs, so it must be either supratentorial or infratentorial. the left side of the tongue is paralyzed; this is either a lmn lesion of the hypoglossal nerve, or a lesion of the hypoglossal nucleus or it’s an umn lesion of the cbt to the hypoglossal nucleus….. if it were a lesion of the hypoglossal nerve (i.e. pns), would there be long-tract signs? if it were a lmn lesion, what side would the lesion be on? if it were an umn lesion what side would the lesion be on? there is an umn-type weakness on the right side of the body (arm and leg) is it possible for the lesion to be below the point of decussation? i.e. in the spinal cord? if it is above the point of decussation, what side is it on? the dc/ml is affected is it possible for the lesion to be below the point of decussation? i.e. in the spinal cord? if it is above the point of decussation, what side is it on? where is the lesion? by the end of today, you’ll be able to tell me what vessel was involved.

19d question 2 11 previous next a 54-year old man was sitting in temple when he suddenly doubled over from excruciating mid-back pain. as the pain wore off over the next half hour, he became aware that he could not move his legs or feel any pain when he pinched them. when he was examined in the hospital, it was found that he had a complete absence of ability to recognize sharpness bilaterally, up to the level of the nipple. nor could he distinguish warm from cold. both pin prick and temperature sensation were normal above this level. below that approximate level he perceived touch normally, or nearly so; vibration and position sense were completely intact throughout. he had no voluntary control over his lower limbs. where is the lesion? be specific. explain the patient’s weakness and sensory signs. the onset suggests stroke. by the end of the day, you’ll be able to tell me what vessel was involved.

19d question 3 12 previous next you are shadowing a family physician, and a 45-year-old woman presents with pain in her neck and right shoulder, and a funny “prickling” or “tingling” sensation in her right arm. she describes the pain as generally being dull and aching, although intermittently, when she moves her neck quickly, she experiences sharp pain shooting from her neck, along the lateral aspect of her arm, and into her thumb. her family doctor finds the following on examination: decreased right biceps reflex triceps reflexes are symmetrical, as are the patellar and achilles reflexes weakness in flexion of the right elbow and supination of the right forearm; power is otherwise symmetrical cranial nerve function is normal power, reflexes and sensation are normal in both lower limbs, and in her left arm where is the lesion? be specific. let’s take it further…. what is the most likely lesion causing her symptoms?

19d question 4 13 previous next a 71-year old, right-handed man was brought to the emergency room because of incoherence and confusion. neurologic examination revealed a right-sided facial weakness with the forehead spared. sensation from the right side of the face was absent. he spoke spontaneously in fluent phrases that were depleted of nouns and uttered many expressions like “oh, you know” and “i guess so”. he did not respond to verbal requests to (for example) close his eyes tightly or stick out his tongue, but could mimic actions performed by the examiner. he could not name objects, but when a pencil was put into his right hand, he held it appropriately and started to scribble aimlessly on his tray table. when the examiner hummed the tune of “jingle bells” the patient sang one line of the song recognizably. when the patient’s brother entered the room, the patient smiled and reached out for his sibling. in which of the four clinical levels of the nervous system is the lesion? why? on which side? would you describe his speech deficit as a receptive / sensory deficit or a motor deficit? where, anatomically, are the following functional areas? sensory speech (wernicke’s) area motor speech (broca’s) area 1° motor cortex for the face 1° somatosensory cortex for the face visual association cortex by the end of the day, you will be able to say vessel is involved.

19.1 blood supply to the cns back to station selection specimens wet whole brain wet half brain next

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: describe the blood supply of the cns. identify major blood vessels in wet specimens, sections and in images (angiograms, mri, etc.). identify / describe the vascular territories of the cns in wet brains and images (ct, mri). 19.1 objectives 2 previous next

19.1 introduction the cns begins as an avascular tubular structure. blood vessels that supply the nervous system first form a network on the surface, from which penetrating vessels arise and grow into the nervous tissue. within the cranium, the major vessels form an anastomotic circle around the base of the brain, and vessels on the surface form anastomoses via smaller branches. once the vessels penetrate the brain, however, they become end arteries, i.e. they do not anastomose with each other. within neural tissue, penetrating arteries branch extensively, forming a dense vascular network. the density of the capillary bed varies considerably among brain areas and is about twice as high in gray matter as in white matter. in the embryo, when the vessels encounter neural tissue, they differentiate to form the tight junctions characteristic of the blood-interstitial fluid barrier . within the choroid plexus the vessels form a dense network of fenestrated capillaries that supply the raw materials for csf formation. the choroid plexus is a complex, gill-like structure that consists of a dense, fenestrated vascular core covered by a tight, secretory epithelium derived from ependymal cells. the high density of vessels makes the choroid plexus appear bright on ct scans (since the iron in the blood is radio dense). it is the choroid epithelium that actually controls the composition of csf and maintains the integrity of the blood-csf barrier . the blood-brain barrier, includes both the blood-isf and blood-csf barriers. in general, large vessels approach the brain from its ventral surface, send penetrating arteries directly into the brain and large circumferential branches around its lateral surface, from which penetrating vessels arise. the pattern of arterial distribution that results is fairly consistent, and is referred to as vascular territories. realize that vascular territories vary between individuals, and that within an individual, there is overlap between adjacent territories, and differences between the left & right sides. the vascular territories presented here represent the “normal” or most common pattern. 3 previous next

19.1 two pairs of major vessels supply the brain 4 previous next branches of the internal carotid arteries (icas) supply antero-superior portions of the cerebrum and the anterior diencephalon. the vertebral arteries (vas) and their branches supply the brainstem & cerebellum, the posteroinferior portions of the cerebrum and the posterior diencephalon how do these vessels gain access to the interior of the cranium? the icas traverse the carotid canal . the vas enter via the foramen magnum .

19.1 the four vessels anastomose at the base of the brain 5 previous next each ica gives off a branch, the anterior cerebral artery (aca) which turns medially to enter the median longitudinal fissure, and continues on the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere. the two acas are joined across the midline by the anterior communicating artery (acom). each ica continues in the lateral fissure as the middle cerebral artery (mca). meanwhile, back at the foramen magnum….. the vas enter alongside the medulla. at the pontomedullary junction, they unite, forming the basilar arteries (ba). the ba ascends over the “belly” of the pons, and at the junction of the pons and midbrain, it bifurcates, forming the two posterior cerebral arteries (pca). the pcas wrap around the mibrain. the pcas and icas are joined by the posterior communicating arteries (pcom).

19.1 the circle of willis 6 previous next nine arteries make up the circle of willis (the mca is not included). blood does not “circle” in the circle of willis . at any branch point, blood flow into each artery is determined by their relative resistance. usually, each ica fills the ipsilateral mca & aca. usually, the ba fills both pcas. however, there are common variations…..

19.1 vascular supply of the cerebral hemispheres 7 previous next learn your vascular territories by studying arteries in context. by taking note of the surfaces over which arteries travel, you can deduce the regions they supply. follow the course of the major blood vessels as described on the following slides. note how the blood vessels course within the subarachnoid space in the various sulci. on the wet specimens provided, t a s k

19.1 the internal carotid system 8 previous next identify the following arteries on the surface of the brain using your wet specimen. tas k start by identifying the ica. note the point where the ica gives rise to the aca, beyond which the ica becomes the mca. follow the mca and its branches into the lateral fissure and over the superolateral surface and temporal pole of the cerebral hemisphere. gently separate the frontal lobes and identify the aca and its branches coursing over the frontal pole and medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere. note, however, that its terminal branches arc over the superior border of the cerebral hemisphere to supply a narrow strip of the superolateral surface. identify the acom joining the right and left acas. note any variations of the artery - sometimes both acas are perfused from one side, via an enlarged acom . to summarize, the ica supplies most of the superolateral surface and temporal pole of the cerebrum via the mca, and the majority of the medial surface and frontal pole of the cerebrum via the aca. penetrating branches supply the basal ganglia. the distribution of these penetrating arteries will be studied later. lastly, identify the anterior choroidal a. , the last branch of the ica before it gives rise to the aca. it is a small vessel that follows the path of the optic tract adjacent to the parahippocampal gyrus .

19.1 cerebral angiograms: ica fill 9 previous next an angiogram is an image of blood vessels to obtain a conventional cerebral angiogram, a bolus of radio-opaque substance is injected into a blood vessel (either the ica or the va) and a rapid series of x-rays is taken as the substance passes through the vasculature. usually, lateral and ap (anteroposterior, frontal) views are obtained. as you now know, the ica will normally fill the aca, mca and branches let’s see how many vessels you can identify in an ica angiogram, both ap and lateral views.

19.1 the vertebrobasilar system i 10 previous next identify as many of the following arteries as possible. start at the medulla. on the wet specimens provided, t a s k depending on the level at which the brainstem was cut, you may or may not see the vertebral arteries (a). identify the basilar artery (b), formed by the union of the right and left vas at the pontomedullary junction. follow the ba over the ventral surface of the pons to its terminal bifurcation, where it forms the posterior cerebral arteries (c). follow the pcas around the midbrain and onto the inferior surface of the cerebral hemisphere to the occipital pole. penetrating branches of the pcas supply the midbrain and posterior portions of the thalamus. identify the posterior communicating as (d), one on each side connecting the pca and the ica. the pcom supplies anterior portions of the thalamus.

19.1 the vertebrobasilar system ii 11 previous next identify as many of the following arteries as possible. identify the superior cerebellar as (e) where they arise from the side of the ba near its terminal bifurcation. continuing with the wet specimens provided, t a s k follow them over the superior surface of the cerebellum. identify the anterior inferior cerebellar as (aicas; f); they arise from the side of the basilar a near its origin at the pontomedullary junction. follow it over the middle cerebellar peduncle and the anterolateral portions of the inferior surface of the cerebellar hemisphere . identify the posterior inferior cerebellar as (picas; g), if present. they arise from the vas closer to the spinomedullary junction. follow the picas over the posteriomedial portions of the inferior surface of the cerebellar hemisphere . to summarize, branches of the vertebral-basilar system of arteries are generally responsible for supplying blood to the brainstem, cerebellum, the diencephalon, and the inferior surface and occipital pole of the cerebrum.
19.1 cerebral angiograms: va fill 12 previous next let’s see how many vessels you can identify in a vertebral artery angiogram, both ap and lateral views.

19.1 vascular territories of the cerebral medullary centre 13 previous next cerebral arteries give rise to penetrating vessels that supply the structures of the cerebral medullary centre, both gray and white. in this figure illustrating a coronal section through the brain, the vascular territories of the aca, mca and pca are separated by red dotted lines. start by identifying the structures (left) and arteries (right) indicated in this figure. click here for the answer, but remember, think: then click:

19.1 vascular territory of the aca 14 previous next read the following with reference to the figure provided. you know that the anterior cerebral arteries and their branches, the callosomarginal and pericallosal arteries, supply the medial surfaces of the frontal and parietal lobes, as well as the adjacent cortex of the superolateral surface. penetrating branches arise from the acas and anterior communicating artery to supply much of the corpus callosum, as well as the inferior portion of the head of the caudate nucleus. in your mind, include these structures in the aca territory.

19.1 vascular territory of the mca 15 previous next read the following with reference to the figure provided. you now know that the middle cerebral arteries (mcas) and their branches run in the lateral sulcus and supply the superolateral surfaces of the cerebral hemispheres and the temporal lobes. penetrating arteries arising from the mca called striate arteries supply a major portion of the corpus striatum. note the structures that fall within their vascular territory: the superior portions of the head of the caudate, the putamen, much of the globus pallidus, and the internal capsule. in your mind, include these structures in the mca territory.

16 previous next 19.1 vascular territories in horizontal section this image is at the level indicated by the horizontal line in the inset. again, identify the structures indicated. check your answers here:

17 previous next 19.1 progress check 1 since embarking on this exercise, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: describe the two components of the blood brain barrier. name the nine arteries that make up the circle of willis. most commonly, which cerebral arteries are fed by the ica? the basilar artery? describe two common variations in the circle of willis that deviate from this pattern. identify, and describe both the anatomical and functional areas of distribution of the aca, anterior communicating artery, pericallosal and callosomarginal as; the ica, anterior choroidal artery, mca and its branches, the posterior communicating arteries and the pca. which vessels supply motor cortex, primary somatosensory cortex, internal capsule, visual cortex, primary auditory cortex, sensory speech area, motor speech area, etc, when presented with one of the fours standard angiograms, identify the artery filled, the aspect from which the image is taken, and identify the main arterial branches. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.

19.1 vascular territories of the brainstem 18 previous next this schematic shows the vessels of the vertebrobasilar system in the context of the brainstem, cerebellum and occipital lobe. it also indicates the six brainstem levels you learned in 20.2. the following slides will add the vascular supply at each level.

19.1 vascular territories of the midbrain 19 previous next look at the schematic below. what vessel is closely associated with the midbrain? at the level of the rostral midbrain (top) all structures are supplied by this artery. at the level of the caudal midbrain, all structures except the inferior colliculi are supplied by this artery. what artery is associated with the junction of the pons and midbrain? this artery supplies the inferior colliculi. click here for the answer:

19.1 vascular territories of the pons 20 previous next look at the schematic below. what vessel is closely associated with the ventral pons? at the level of the mid-pons (top) all structures except those at its most dorsal aspect are supplied by this artery. at the level of the caudal pons, all structures except those most dorsolateral are supplied by this artery. what is this white matter structure? if you remember, you should be able to figure out what artery supplies it. what is this white matter structure? if you remember, you should be able to figure out what artery supplies this area. click here for the answer:

19.1 vessels that supply the medulla 21 previous next in order to understand the vascular territories associated with the medulla, you must meet two more arteries. in this graphic, you see the vertebral arteries (a) giving rise to the posterior inferior cerebellar arteries (b). notice artery c, the anterior spinal artery. it forms by the union of a ramus from each of the vertebral arteries. the anterior spinal artery is unpaired, and occupies the ventral median fissure. notice arteries d, the posterior spinal arteries. these bilaterally-paired arteries are usually branches of the pica. the posterior spinal arteries descend in the dorsolateral sulcus, in the company of the dorsal rootlets. next we’ll look at cross sections of the medulla, and place these vessels around them in order to understand its vascular territories.

19.1 vascular territories of the medulla 22 previous next the cross sections of the medulla are cut at the levels of the blue dotted lines in the graphic below. in the cross sections, vascular territories are separated by red dotted lines, and arteries on the surface of the brainstem are represented by red circles. look at the cross section of the rostral medulla: starting in the anterior midline, and with reference to the figure below, identify the arteries supplying each vascular territory. look at the cross section of the caudal medulla: a single vessel is in the ventral median fissure, and a pair of vessels are lateral to it. two more vessels are dorsolateral, and the final two are adjacent to the fasciculus cuneatus. can you identify them? click here for the answer:

19.1 vascular territories of the spinal cord 23 previous next in this figure, identify the anterior spinal artery and follow its branches both into the ventral median fissure and around the circumference of the cord. note that the penetrating branches of the anterior spinal artery supply the white matter of the ventral and lateral columns and the gray matter of the ventral horns. locate the posterior spinal arteries and note also how its branches penetrate and supply the dorsal columns of white matter and the dorsal horns of the spinal gray matter. vascular diseases of the spinal cord are most often confined to the distribution of the anterior spinal artery. what long tracts travel in the territory of the anterior spinal artery, and are therefore affected in this scenario? what long tracts travel in the territory of the posterior spinal artery and are therefore unaffected? discuss this with your group.

19.1 radicular and segmental medullary arteries 24 previous next at every segmental level, a spinal artery enters the intervertebral foramen on both sides alongside the spinal nerve. in the neck, spinal arteries are branches of either the vertebral or cervical arteries. in the thorax and abdomen, spinal arteries arise from the dorsal branches of the intercostal arteries and the lumbar arteries, respectively. most spinal arteries end as radicular arteries. anterior and posterior radicular arteries travel with their respective nerve roots, ending at the dorsolateral and ventrolateral sulci where the nerve roots meet the spinal cord. locate the radicular arteries in this figure. a smaller number of spinal arteries end as anterior and posterior segmental medullary arteries, which extend to the anterior and posterior spinal arteries, respectively, reinforcing the blood flow along the length of the cord. these larger segmental medullary arteries are usually located in the lower cervical, lower thoracic and upper lumbar regions. the largest of these, an anterior radicular artery known as the spinal artery of adamkiewicz, is usually situated in the lower thoracic or upper lumbar region.

25 previous next 19.1 progress check 2 since the last progress check, you have identified the following structures and learned the answers to the following questions: identify the vessels of the vertebrobasilar system in a wet brain specimen. when presented with one of the six brainstem levels learned, identify the relevant vascular territories. name the grey and white matter structures within each of these vascular territories. for instance, which vessel supplies the cst at each level of the brainstem? describe the origin and course of the anterior and posterior spinal arteries, as well as their vascular territories. name the grey and white matter structures within each of these vascular territories. describe the location and distribution of radicular and segmental medullary arteries. if you are satisfied with your ability to identify these structures and answer these questions, call your ta over for confirmation and for permission to move on.
