19.2 the medullary centre back to station selection specimens a wet half-brain for dissection these are different from the half brains at your stations – do not dissect the brains at your stations, which must remain intact for review. each lab has been provided with a container of half brains that are specifically meant to be dissected. your ta will show you where it is. next

when you have learned the material presented in this exercise, you will be able to: identify / describe the internal structure of the cerebral hemispheres, including major nuclei and white matter structures, in dissections, cross-sections and images. describe the effects of lesions in various locations within the cerebral hemisphere. 19.2 objectives 2 previous next

19.2 introduction in lab exercise 18.3, you studied the surface features of the brain and were introduced to the concept of functional localization in the cerebral cortex. in lab exercise 19.2, you will dissect a cerebral hemisphere to learn what lies beneath the surface. you will find and identify major white matter tracts and grey matter structures, while at the same time being introduced to their functions and connections. this approach will prepare you to think about the deficits that would result from lesions in each of these structures. while dissecting, you will be referred to a series of cross sections, and correlate what you see in three dimensions, in your hands, with what you see in two dimensions, on the screen. this exercise will teach you how to recognize anatomical structures in diagnostic images. the dissection is divided into three parts as follows: subcortical white matter the basal nuclei (ganglia) and internal capsule the ventricular system and diencephalon a word about dissection technique: you have learned by now that the body is built in layers. you took advantage of these layers whenever you used blunt dissection techniques, whether using blunt tools or your fingers. the brain is no different. you will use, largely, blunt dissection. there is only one point in the dissection of a brain that requires a sharp instrument. otherwise, you will use your fingers, and / or the back of a scalpel handle or a blunt probe. 3 previous next

19.2 part 1: subcortical white matter 4 previous next deep to the cerebral cortex is the subcortical white matter. it consists of axons connecting different areas of the nervous system. it can be classified as follows: commissural fibres connect the two hemispheres across the midline; e.g. the corpus callosum (a) and anterior commissure projection fibres carry information, in either direction, between a cerebral hemisphere and some lower centre (brainstem, spinal cord); e.g. the axons of the corona radiata (b) funnel together to get around or between medullary grey matter, forming the internal capsule (c) and external capsule (d), which coalesce to form, for instance, the cerebral peduncles (e). association fibres connect different regions within a given hemisphere from neuroanatomy: an atlas of structures, sections and systems, 8e, by d. e. haines, © 2012, lww.

19.2 the cingulum and corpus callosum 5 previous next the corpus callosum is composed of commissural fibres. identify its rostrum, genu, body and splenium. remove portions of the cingulum adjacent to the splenium and genu of the corpus callosum laterally to expose the forceps major and forceps minor . r. cerebral hemisphere, medial view. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage. on the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere, use your scalpel handle to scrape off tas k the cortex of the cingulate and parahippocampal gyri to expose the association fibres that make up the cingulum. note how the cingulum courses above the corpus callosum and into the parahippocampal gyrus and uncus.

19.2 the superior longitudinal fasciculus 6 previous next superior longitudinal fasciculus, association fibres that connect the frontal, parietal, occipital and temporal cortex. the superior longitudinal fasciculus is most easily found as it courses deep to the inferior parietal lobule and inferior part of the post central gyrus. use your scalpel handle or fingers on the lateral surface of the hemisphere dissect out the tas k to remove the cortex and short association fibers from the inferior parietal lobule and the inferior part of the post central gyrus until you find the long fibers of the superior longitudinal fasciculus. r. cerebral hemisphere, lateral view, superficial dissection. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage. once identified at this site, to see it in its entirety, follow this cleavage plane into the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes, by removing the cortex and short association fibres superficial to it.

19.2 the corona radiata and inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus 7 previous next superior longitudinal fasciculus. expose the fibers of the inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus (association fibres) in the occipital lobe. the inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus, like the corona radiata, lies on a deeper plane relative to the superior longitudinal fasciculus. next, expose the corona radiata (projection fibres) deep to the tas k this figure illustrates an intermediate dissection demonstrating the corona radiata and part of the inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus. a segment of the superior longitudinal fasciculus (slf) has been left to illustrate its relative position. notice the insula. before you proceed with thedissection, it’s important to remind you about the insula and its relationship to thestructures deep to it . r. cerebral hemisphere, lateral view, intermediate dissection. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage.

19.2 the external capsule and uncinate fasciculus 8 previous next projection fibres and is a continuation of the corona radiata deep to the insula. next, expose the uncinate fasciculus, association fibres connecting the temporal and frontal remove the insula to reveal the external capsule. it is composed of tas k poles, by peeling away the cortex on the superior surface of the temporal pole and adjacent orbital surface of the frontal lobe. the inferior occipitofrontal fasciculus can be seen lying posterior and superior to the uncinate fasciculus, and continuing into the frontal lobe. r. cerebral hemisphere, lateral view, deep dissection. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage.

19.2 part 2: the basal ganglia and internal capsule 9 previous next the basal nuclei (ganglia) of the cerebral hemispheres are the caudate nucleus (c), the putamen (d), the globus pallidus (e), the substantia nigra and the subthalamic nucleus. the putamen and globus pallidus are anatomically related, and together are called the lentiform nucleus. the caudate and putamen are functionally related, and together are referred to as the striatum. all three structures are referred to as the corpus striatum. notice that the putamen is immediately deep to the external capsule. it will be revealed in the next step of the dissection. the substantia nigra is a midbrain structure, and is therefore not seen in this diagram, which does not include the midbrain. the subthalamic nucleus is small and difficult to locate in most scans; it is not illustrated. notice, from the inset at the top of the figure, that this is a coronal section through the cerebral hemisphere, cut through the frontal lobe, lateral fissure (red dotted line) and temporal lobe. the cerebral cortex is not the only collection of grey matter in the cerebral hemispheres. grey matter structures are buried within the cerebral hemispheres. these are the diencephalon, which includes the paired thalami (a) and hypothalamus (b), and the basal nuclei (basal ganglia). l. cerebral hemisphere, coronal section. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage.

19.2 the corpus striatum and lateral ventricles 10 previous next in this figure, the ventricular system and grey matter structures are overlaid on the left cerebral hemisphere. the lateral ventricle is shaded dark grey, and can be seen to extend into the frontal lobe, as the anterior horn, through the parietal lobe as the body, into the occipital lobe as the posterior horn, and into the temporal lobe as the inferior horn. the corpus striatum is depicted in blue. the caudate nucleus is long and tapered. it starts as a bulbous head in the floor of the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. its tapered body is in the floor of the body of the lateral ventricle. its tail extends into the roof of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. the head of the caudate is continuous with the anterior pole of the putamen. the putamen is the most lateral component of the lentiform. the projection fibres of the internal capsule pass between the lentiform nucleus and the thalamus. this is seen more clearly here:

19.2 the putamen 11 previous next capsule to expose the lateral surface of the putamen. note how the fibres of the corona radiata are now disappearing deep to the putamen. in doing so, they form the internal capsule. you will recognize the putamen by its more homogeneous texture, as compared to the fibrous appearance of the external capsule. dissecting from lateral to medial, remove the fibers of the external tas k r. cerebral hemisphere, lateral view, deepest dissection. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage. the optic radiation consists of axons relaying information from the lateral geniculate nucleus of the thalamus to the visual cortex of the occipital lobe.

19.2 the internal capsule 12 previous next using a scalpel, make a careful horizontal cut tas k nucleus, the globus pallidus. removal of a portion of the lentiform in this manner will reveal the continuation of the corona radiata as the internal capsule. the internal capsule consists of projection fibres running medial to the lentiform nucleus. anteriorly, it lies between the lentiform and the head of the caudate nucleus, forming the anterior limb of the internal capsule. posteriorly, the internal capsule lies between the lentiform and the thalamus forming the posterior limb of the internal capsule. the inflection point between the anterior and posterior limbs of the internal capsule is the genu. identify these structures in the accompanying figure. to better understand the corpus striatum in this horizontal section, click here: through the lentiform and remove its superior half. look, in the cut surface, the more fibrous, and therefore paler, portion of the lentiform l. cerebral hemisphere, horizontal section. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage.

19.2 part 3: the ventricular system and diencephalon i 13 previous next before you continue with the dissection, we’ll review the ventricular system and diencephalon. the ventricular system is a continuous series of csf-filled spaces that develops from the lumen of the neural tube. a portion of the ventricular system is associated with each subdivision of the cns. csf is formed by choroid plexus, modified blood vessels located in the ventricular spaces. a lateral ventricle is found within each cerebral hemisphere. it is irregular in shape, extending into the frontal, parietal and temporal lobes forming roughly the shape of the letter “c”. i) the portion in the frontal lobe is the anterior horn, ii) the portion in the parietal lobe is the body, and iii) the portion extending into the temporal lobe is the inferior horn. iv) usually, but not always, a posterior horn extends into the occipital lobe. v) the body and inferior horn (and posterior horn, if present) unite at the trigone or atrium.

19.2 part 3: the ventricular system and diencephalon ii 14 previous next each lateral ventricle opens via an interventricular foramen into the third ventricle, a midline slit separating the two thalami and extending into the lumen of the hypothalamus as the hypothalamic recess. the third ventricle drains via the cerebral aqueduct through the midbrain. as this is the narrowest portion of the ventricular system, it is the most commonly occluded, which can lead to hydrocephalus. the cerebral aqueduct opens into the fourth ventricle, which is associated with the pons and medulla, anteriorly, and the cerebellum, posteriorly. in the lab you will find a model tas k of a ventricular cast. on it, identify the components of the ventricular system, including the subdivisions of the lateral ventricles.

19.2 subarachnoid cisterns and the flow of csf 15 previous next csf leaves the ventricular space through three openings in the 4th ventricle. one, the median aperture opens in the midline between the medulla and the cerebellum. the other two are the paired lateral apertures (not shown), which open at the cerebellopontine angles. through these openings, csf enters the subarachnoid space, and bathes the outer surface of the cns. csf flows around the cns, and ultimately is absorbed across the arachnoid granulations into the venous blood of the dural venous sinuses, as well as into the lymphatics that surround nerves. the flow of csf is significant; it turns over 3 times each day. the subarachnoid space is expanded in places, where it forms cisterns. you’ve already encountered the lumbar cistern. there are numerous cisterns around the brain, but the largest and most easily seen are the superior cistern, the cisterna magna and the interpeduncular cistern. find them in the diagram

16 previous next on the medial surface of the cerebral hemisphere, locate the thalamus (a). tas k because the thalami are paired, and the third ventricle is a midline slit located between them, the right and left thalami form the lateral walls of the third ventricle. in your specimen, when the cerebral hemispheres were bisected, the third ventricle was opened and the thalamus you see in your specimen is one of the lateral walls of this space. you may see choroid plexus (b) in the roof of the third ventricle. choroid plexus is modified blood vessels that secrete csf into the ventricular system. 19.2 exploring the ventricular system and diencephalon locate the corpus callosum (c). because it is a midline structure, your specimen may or may not contain the septum pellucidum (d), a membrane that separates the anterior horns of the right and left lateral ventricles. it extends from the corpus callosum to the fornix (e), a tract connecting the hippocampus with the mamillary bodies. place a probe between the fornix and the anterior pole of the thalamus. this is the interventricular foramen (f) and the tip of your probe is now in the anterior horn of the lateral ventricle. because the cerebral aqueduct (g) of the midbrain is so narrow, it is unlikely (but not impossible!) that your brainstem will show this portion of the ventricular system. you will certainly see the fourth ventricle (h). place your probe between the posterior surface of the medulla and the cerebellum. this is the location of the median aperture, through which csf passes into the cisterna magna. you may find choroid plexus in the median aperture (i).

19.2 the lateral aperture 17 previous next from the ventral aspect. find the cerebellopontine angle, the point at which the cerebellum meets the junction of the pons and medulla. in the cerebellopontine angle, you will likely find turn the specimen so that you are looking at the brainstem tas k a small tuft of choroid plexus (a). the choroid plexus in this location has been pushed by the flow of csf out of the fourth ventricle through the lateral aperture (of lushka) and into the subarachnoid space of the cerebellopontine angle. using this landmark as the location of the lateral aperture, you may be able to carefully advance the tip of your probe from the fourth ventricle through the lateral aperture and into the cerebellopontine angle. by performing this exercise, you will appreciate the location of the lateral aperture, and better understand the flow of csf. vestibular schwannoma info is a benign tumour arising from the schwann cells of c.n. viii, the vestibulocochlear nerve. initial signs involve balance and hearing, but as it grows to occupy the cerebellopontine angle, it can compress adjacent nerves, starting with the facial and trigeminal nerves, and the brainstem, itself.

19.2 opening the lateral ventricle 18 previous next corona radiata into the anterior horn, body, posterior horn and inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. identify the c-shaped caudate nucleus and note the relationships of its subdivisions to those of the lateral ventricle: locate its head bulging into the floor of the anterior horn, its body next, from a lateral approach, use a scalpel to cut through the tas k in the floor of the body of the lateral ventricle and its tail coursing into the roof of the inferior horn. the caudate nucleus terminates at the amygdala in the uncus. note also the hippocampus bulging into the floor of the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle. from the lateral aspect, look into the lateral ventricle and identify the thalamus. it forms the floor of the body of the lateral ventricle, while the corpus callosum forms its roof. note that fibers of the internal capsule pass between the head of the caudate and lentiform nucleus anteriorly and between the thalamus and lentiform nucleus posteriorly. these fibers are coursing through the anterior and posterior limbs of the internal capsule, respectively. r. cerebral hemisphere, lateral view, lateral ventricle opened. from serial dissections of the human brain, by carlton g. smith, m.d., ph.d., © 1981 by gage.

19.2 choroid plexus and csf 19 previous next the function of the choroid plexuses is to secrete cerebrospinal fluid (csf) at a rate of 500 ml/day. the total volume of csf is about 150 ml, so this fluid is turned over three times per day. csf is continuous with the extracellular fluid within neural tissue. it is similar in some ways to plasma, identify the choroid plexus in all four ventricles. tas k but its concentrations of protein, potassium, calcium and magnesium are lower than in plasma. csf circulates through the subarachnoid space and is returned into the vascular system through: i) the arachnoid granulations that protrude into the superior sagittal sinus, and ii) by lymphatics located around the sheaths of the cranial nerves, particularly the olfactory nerves. csf functions to bathe the internal and external surfaces of the brain and spinal cord removing metabolites and maintaining a constant extracellular environment. in addition, it provides a mechanical cushion protecting the brain from impact with the surrounding bone when the head moves, and it allows the brain to float, thereby reducing its effective weight to less than 50 g. hydrocephalus (water in the head) can result from:i) overproduction of csf (rare), ii) impaired absorption of csf, or iii) obstruction of the drainage pathways. the location of an obstruction can be deduced from the pattern of ventricular enlargement, if one keeps in mind the flow of csf. ventricular spaces upstream of the obstruction will be enlarged, those downstream of the obstruction will be normal. the most common site of obstruction is the narrow cerebral aqueduct. in an infant, whose skull bones have not yet fused, hydrocephalus results in an enlarged head if left untreated. in an adult whose skull bones have fused, hydrocephalus results in an increase in intracranial pressure.

19.2 the cerebellum 20 previous next isolated, whole cerebella, both wet and plastinated, are available tas k at the centre table. do not cut the cerebellum off the specimens at your station. superior vermis cerebellar hemisphere primary fissure anterior lobe posterior lobe identify the following features on the superior surface of a cerebellum: identify the following features on the inferior surface of a cerebellum: inferior vermis cerbellar hemisphere posterior lobe flocculus tonsil
